results.title: Screens and screams
results.brief_description: Kids’ Own Publishing Partnership will have a series of workshops and resultant exhibition which aims : to promote reading including visual literacy, to engage children in the creative process of working together towards a shared outcome, to produce a number of digital stories, to stimulate publishing in schools beyond the boundaries of the project, to extend children’s experience as readers and writers and illustrators.

results.title: Screening Nuclear Hazard
results.brief_description: An attempt to show how a complicated and sensitive issue is handled by television. The example used is a BBC Horizon program produced in 1979 and entitled “Elements of Risk”. The film examines the conception, shooting and editing of the program. Begins with a brief discussion of how the same issue is handled by BBC News

results.title: Screening Middlemarch: [19th. century] novel to 90's TV
results.brief_description: Takes the student and the teacher behind the scenes to offer fascinating insights into the complex task of bringing a great 19th Century novel to the television screen. It uses authentic materials from different aspects of the TV and radio production process. It gives opportunities to compare George Eliot’s original text with the radio adaptation, the TV production and the screenwriter’s version, by using excerpts from the actual dramatisation. Allows both teachers and students the opportunity to re-edit some of the shots taken by the production team, and to compare their versions with the broadcast version. It examines the roles of sound effects and music in relation to narrative and realism. This programme will not only teach the process of turning a book into a television serial, but by examining such concepts as narrative, realism, character, gender, class and the use of the authorial voice, will also help students with the study of the novel generally. The kit contains one 90 minute videocassette, one 60 minute audiocassette and one comprehensive activity book.

results.title: Screen Worlds opening : September 2009
results.brief_description:
On Thursday September 17, 2009 ACMI’s new permanent screen culture exhibition Screen Worlds, was officially launched. The red carpet, VIP event attracted world wide attention with the attendance of both internationally recognised and home grown guests and artists. Kicking off the formalities was ACMI’s Board President, John Thwaites, followed by ACMI Director Tony Sweeney, Oscar® Winning Actress Cate Blanchett, Victorian Arts Minister Lynne Kosky and Victorian Premier John Brumby.
Following this, the ribbon is cut and guests enter the exhibition for the first time.

results.title: Screen worlds : Interview with Ab Rogers
results.brief_description: British designer Ab Rogers is founder and head of a multi-disciplinary studio in London ARD (Ab Rogers Desgin). Ab visited ACMI in December 2008 and the Content Development crew interviewed him in relation to his design and intent behind the Screen Worlds exhibition. He spoke about the tendering process, the challenges of designing for the Federation Square space, his overall approach to design and a brief introduction to the three sections, Emergence, Voices and Sensation.

results.title: Screen sports development workshop
results.creator_credit: Public Programs - Events (Helen Simondson) and Paul Fletcher
results.brief_description:
The SCREENSPORTS event is a unique, entertaining and informative ‘CINEMA EXPERIENCE’. SCREENSPORTS represents an historic leap in the marriage of live performance and technology. It has the potential to be an ACMI flagship pioneering new international standards in screen-based performance. Based on the highly successful Theatre Sports;live improvisation performance the Screensports concept draws on screen culture and the screen as the basis for live improvisation.

A troupe of actors are thrown into virtual worlds utilising the ACMI template sets and the globecaster technology. The actors use these sets as a stimulus for fast and hilarious improvisation.
Screen sports will be fun and informative and appeal to a wide range of people.
In order to develop the Screensports performance it is crucial to conduct a creative development workshop to produce the content for the live performance.

results.title: Eye of fire
results.brief_description: A gas leak in an underwater pipeline caused an oceanic fireball dubbed ‘The Eye of Fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico. The state owned company is investigating the causes.

constellations_other.name: Deep blue
constellations_other.description: Go deep on an exploration of real world oceans and those rendered by pixels and creatures made from plastics.

results.title_for_label: ‘Eye of fire’ in the Gulf of Mexico
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In horrific scenes that seemed more like footage from an action movie than the real world, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The huge fireball blazing across the sea surface was caused by a gas leak from an underwater pipeline, which social media users dubbed ‘the eye of fire’. The video was shared across the internet as further evidence of the environmental tolls of capitalism and the irresponsibility of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.
description_for_label:
This responsive display presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

In astonishing scenes, the ocean was literally on fire on 3 July 2021 in the Gulf of Mexico. The fireball blazing across the sea surface, dubbed the ‘eye of fire’ by social media users, was caused by an underwater gas leak from a pipeline. The video spread across the internet as further evidence of fossil fuel companies plundering natural resources and producing unnatural results.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Screen magazine. No. 8
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This is the United Nations”
Cinemagazine items: 1. UN at work on world wide system of road signs - An amusing allegory with cartoons by Steinburg. Explains how the two different systems used in Europe and America make it difficult for a travelling motorist to find their way outside their own country. 2. Eritrea federated to Ethiopia - Explains how United Nations investigated political problems posed by Eritrea, a former Italian colony on the Red Sea. The population was divided in race and religion; the land poor; political opinions strongly divided; some sought independence; some wanted union with Ethiopia. After the report by a UN Commission, the General Assembly decided to federate the country to Ethiopia within two years.

results.title: Screen Magazine. No. 25. A New future for Somaliland
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the United Nations Advisory Council which was sent to Somaliland to advise the Italian Trusteeship Administration there. Help has been given on the development of a democratic government and judicial system, establishment of medical services, organisation of education, and the development of agriculture and industry.
